articles.title: Tendo Calcaneus Injury
articles.author: Sachintha Sathsara
articles.excerpt:
Tendo-calcaneus is the thickest and strongest tendon in the human body.
It is formed by the gastrocnemius and soleus muscles (¬± plantaris).
It connects these calf muscles to the calcaneus (heel bone).
Its main function is plantar flexion of the foot (standing on toes, walking, running, jumping).
articles.content:
Tendo-Calcaneus (Achilles Tendon) Injury

Introduction

The tendo-calcaneus, commonly known as the Achilles tendon, is the strongest and thickest tendon in the human body. It plays a crucial role in locomotion, posture, and balance. Injury to this tendon significantly affects walking, running, and standing.

Anatomy (B.D. Chaurasia)

  • Formed by convergence of gastrocnemius & soleus (¬± plantaris).
  • Inserts into the middle posterior calcaneus.
  • Covered by a paratenon, not a true synovial sheath.
  • Poor blood supply, especially 2‚Äì6 cm above insertion ‚Üí vulnerable to injury & delayed healing.

Physiology & Function (Guyton & Ganong)

  • Produces plantar flexion via gastrocnemius-soleus complex.
  • Essential for:
    • Standing on toes
    • Push-off phase of gait (walking / running)
    • Posture & balance
  • Stores & releases elastic energy ‚Üí improves locomotor efficiency.

Causes of Injury

  • Sudden forceful calf contraction
  • Excessive ankle dorsiflexion
  • Sports: jumping, sprinting
  • Age-related degeneration
  • Poor tendon vascularity

Types of Injury

  1. Tendinitis / Tendinosis ‚Äì inflammation or degeneration from overuse
  2. Partial tear ‚Äì incomplete rupture
  3. Complete rupture ‚Äì full discontinuity

Clinical Features

  • Sudden sharp pain in heel / lower calf (‚Äúsnap‚Äù or ‚Äúkick from behind‚Äù)
  • Swelling & tenderness above heel
  • Difficulty / inability to stand on toes
  • Loss of plantar flexion strength
  • Positive Thompson test: squeeze calf ‚Üí no plantar flexion (complete rupture)

Functional & Physiological Effects

  • Impaired push-off phase of gait
  • Reduced stability & balance
  • Altered posture (loss of plantar flexor tone)
  • Increased load on other muscles & joints

Management (Brief)

  • Conservative: rest, immobilization, physiotherapy (tendinitis / partial tear)
  • Surgical repair: indicated for complete rupture, especially in young / active patients

Conclusion

Tendo-calcaneus injury causes significant loss of plantar flexion and gait disruption. Its poor blood supply and high functional demand make healing slow; understanding anatomy & physiology is key to optimal management.

Tendo-Calcaneus Injury ‚Äì Treatment

1. Anatomical Basis (B.D. Chaurasia)

  • Formed by gastrocnemius + soleus
  • Inserts mid-posterior calcaneus
  • Strongest tendon but poor blood supply ‚Üí delayed healing
  • Function: plantar flexion (standing, walking, running)

‚û°Ô∏è Goal: Restore plantar flexion & tendon continuity.

2. Physiological Basis (Ganong & Guyton)

  • Muscle contraction needs:
    • Neuromuscular transmission
    • ATP availability
    • Protein synthesis & fiber repair
  • Immobilization ‚Üí disuse atrophy
  • Early controlled mobilization improves:
    • Blood flow
    • Collagen alignment
    • Functional recovery

‚û°Ô∏è Balance immobilization with gradual mobilization.

A. Strain / Partial Tear ‚Äì Conservative Management

  1. RICE: Rest ‚Ä¢ Ice ‚Ä¢ Compression ‚Ä¢ Elevation
  2. Immobilization: below-knee cast/boot in plantar flexion
  3. NSAIDs for pain & inflammation
  4. Physiotherapy (after pain subsides):
    • Gentle stretching
    • Progressive strengthening

Reduced tension ‚Üí collagen repair; gradual loading ‚Üë tensile strength.

B. Complete Rupture

1. Surgical Treatment (young / athletes)

  • End-to-end tendon repair
  • Ankle in plantar flexion post-op
  • Cast immobilization ~6‚Äì8 weeks

Anatomical: restores muscle-tendon length.
Physiological: collagen synthesis & remodeling.

2. Conservative Treatment (elderly / unfit for surgery)

  • Long- or below-knee cast in plantar flexion
  • Gradual dorsiflexion over weeks

‚ö†Ô∏è Higher risk of re-rupture & weak plantar flexion

C. Rehabilitation Phase üèÉ‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è

  1. Physiotherapy
    • Passive ‚Üí active ROM
    • Calf strengthening
  2. Prevent disuse atrophy
    • Electrical stimulation if needed
    • Gradual weight-bearing
  3. Return to function: walking ‚Üí running ‚Üí jumping

Guyton: activity maintains muscle mass & strength.
Ganong: mechanical stress ‚Üí tissue remodeling.

Complications (untreated / poorly treated)

  • Weak plantar flexion
  • Limping gait
  • Calf atrophy
  • Chronic pain

articles.title: Role of Physiotherapy in Stroke Rehabilitation
articles.author: Sachintha Sathsara
articles.excerpt: Discover how physiotherapy plays a crucial role in helping stroke survivors regain mobility, independence, and quality of life through targeted rehabilitation techniques.
articles.content:
Understanding Stroke Rehabilitation

Stroke is one of the leading causes of long-term disability worldwide. When a stroke occurs, it disrupts blood flow to the brain, potentially causing damage that affects movement, speech, cognition, and daily functioning. Physiotherapy is a cornerstone of stroke rehabilitation, helping patients recover lost abilities and adapt to any permanent changes.

Early Intervention Matters

Research consistently shows that early physiotherapy intervention leads to better outcomes. In the acute phase (first few days after stroke), physiotherapists focus on:

  • Preventing complications like pneumonia and blood clots
  • Proper positioning to prevent contractures
  • Early mobilization when medically stable
  • Assessment of functional abilities

Key Physiotherapy Techniques

Modern stroke rehabilitation employs evidence-based techniques including:

  • Task-specific training: Practicing real-world activities
  • Strength training: Rebuilding muscle power
  • Balance exercises: Improving stability and preventing falls
  • Gait training: Relearning to walk safely
  • Constraint-induced movement therapy: Encouraging use of affected limbs

The Recovery Journey

Recovery from stroke is highly individual. While some patients make rapid progress, others require months or years of dedicated therapy. The brain's neuroplasticity‚Äîits ability to form new neural connections‚Äîmeans that improvement can continue long after the initial stroke.

Conclusion

Physiotherapy provides hope and practical solutions for stroke survivors. Through consistent, evidence-based treatment, many patients achieve significant improvements in their mobility and independence.

articles.title: Importance of Posture in Daily Life
articles.author: Sachintha Sathsara
articles.excerpt: Learn why maintaining proper posture is essential for preventing musculoskeletal problems and how small changes can make a significant difference in your health.
articles.content:
What is Good Posture?

Good posture refers to the correct alignment of body parts supported by the right amount of muscle tension against gravity. When we stand, sit, or move with proper posture, we place minimal stress on our muscles, joints, and ligaments.

The Cost of Poor Posture

In our modern world of desk jobs and smartphones, poor posture has become epidemic. The consequences include:

  • Chronic neck and back pain
  • Headaches and migraines
  • Reduced breathing capacity
  • Impaired digestion
  • Decreased energy levels
  • Increased risk of injury

Tips for Better Posture

Improving your posture doesn't have to be complicated:

  • Workspace ergonomics: Adjust your chair, monitor, and keyboard height
  • Take breaks: Stand and stretch every 30-60 minutes
  • Strengthen core muscles: A strong core supports your spine
  • Be mindful: Check in with your body throughout the day
  • Sleep position: Use supportive pillows and mattress

Exercises for Posture

Simple exercises can help correct postural imbalances:

  • Chin tucks for forward head posture
  • Wall angels for shoulder mobility
  • Cat-cow stretches for spinal flexibility
  • Planks for core strength

articles.title: Benefits of Exercise Therapy in Physiotherapy
articles.author: Sachintha Sathsara
articles.excerpt: Exercise therapy is a fundamental component of physiotherapy. Explore the science-backed benefits and how tailored exercise programs promote healing and function.
articles.content:
What is Exercise Therapy?

Exercise therapy involves prescribed physical activities designed to restore normal function, reduce pain, and prevent disability. Unlike general exercise, therapeutic exercises are specifically tailored to address individual health conditions and goals.

Key Benefits

Research supports numerous benefits of exercise therapy:

  • Pain reduction: Exercise releases endorphins and reduces inflammation
  • Improved strength: Targeted exercises rebuild weakened muscles
  • Enhanced flexibility: Stretching maintains joint range of motion
  • Better balance: Reduces fall risk, especially in elderly
  • Cardiovascular health: Aerobic exercise strengthens the heart
  • Mental health: Exercise reduces anxiety and depression

Types of Therapeutic Exercises

  • Range of motion exercises
  • Strengthening exercises
  • Aerobic conditioning
  • Balance and coordination training
  • Functional training

Getting Started

Always consult a qualified physiotherapist before starting an exercise program, especially if you have existing health conditions. They will assess your needs and create a safe, effective plan.

articles.title: Evidence-Based Approaches to Managing Low Back Pain
articles.author: Sachintha Sathsara
articles.excerpt: Low back pain affects millions worldwide. Learn about the latest evidence-based physiotherapy approaches for effective management and prevention.
articles.content:
The Burden of Low Back Pain

Low back pain is one of the most common reasons people seek medical care and miss work. About 80% of adults experience low back pain at some point, making it a significant public health concern.

Understanding the Causes

Most low back pain is 'non-specific,' meaning no specific pathology can be identified. Contributing factors include:

  • Poor posture and ergonomics
  • Weak core muscles
  • Sedentary lifestyle
  • Stress and psychological factors
  • Heavy lifting with poor technique

Evidence-Based Treatments

Current clinical guidelines recommend:

  • Stay active: Bed rest is no longer recommended
  • Exercise therapy: Core strengthening and general exercise
  • Manual therapy: Spinal manipulation and massage
  • Education: Understanding pain and self-management
  • Gradual return to activities: Progressive loading

Prevention Strategies

The best approach is prevention through regular exercise, proper lifting techniques, ergonomic workstations, and maintaining a healthy weight.

articles.title: Preventing Sports Injuries: A Physiotherapist's Guide
articles.author: Sachintha Sathsara
articles.excerpt: Whether you're a professional athlete or weekend warrior, understanding injury prevention can keep you in the game. Learn key strategies from a physiotherapy perspective.
articles.content:
Why Prevention Matters

Sports injuries can sideline athletes for weeks, months, or even end careers. Prevention is always better than treatment, and many common injuries are avoidable with proper preparation.

Common Sports Injuries

  • Ankle sprains
  • Knee injuries (ACL, meniscus)
  • Hamstring strains
  • Tennis elbow
  • Rotator cuff injuries
  • Stress fractures

Prevention Strategies

Warm-Up Properly

A good warm-up increases blood flow, raises muscle temperature, and prepares the nervous system for activity.

Strengthen and Condition

Sport-specific conditioning programs reduce injury risk by preparing the body for the demands of the activity.

Use Proper Technique

Poor form increases injury risk. Consider working with a coach or physiotherapist to optimize your technique.

Allow Recovery

Overtraining is a major cause of injury. Build rest days into your training schedule.

Listen to Your Body

Pain is a warning sign. Don't push through significant discomfort.
